intro: Sclerolaena tetracuspis, commonly known as the four-lobed sandmat, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and hairy stems. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. Its leaves are ovate to lanceolate, with a distinctive four-lobed base, giving it its scientific name. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal or arid environments.
